title: climate change affect our mental health?
intro: How can you protect your mental health from the impacts of climate change? Neil and Beth discuss this and teach you some new vocabulary.
this_week_question: According to research organisation World Weather Attribution, human-caused climate change made the LA wildfires in January 2025:
a)   10% more likely b)   35% more likely c)   20% less likely
Listen to the programme to hear the answer.

vocab.desc: the very bad and long-lasting emotional effects of an event or experience
able to get better more easily when bad things happen
a positive thing that comes from a negative situation

transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I'm Beth.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I'm Neil. Today we're going to talk about climate change and how it can affect people's mental health. Natural disasters and the impacts of climate change can be stressful. Isn't that right, Beth?

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: Yeah, definitely. In today's episode we're going to find out about how people can protect their mental health from the impacts of climate change. We'll be hearing from a psychiatry expert and a man who survived a wildfire and helped rebuild his town.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: But first, Beth, I have a question for you. Scientists aren't always sure whether natural disasters like floods and wildfires are as a result of human-caused climate change. But in January 2025, big wildfires affected big parts of Los Angeles in California. But according to research organisation World Weather Attribution, human-caused climate change made the fires:

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: Erm… I'm going to say 10% more likely.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK. Well, we'll find out the answer at the end of the programme. Now, natural disasters like floods and wildfires can destroy homes and communities.

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: People who live in areas affected by natural disasters can often experience climate trauma . Trauma is what we call the very bad and long-lasting emotional effects of an event or experience.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Professor Jyoti Mishra is an expert in climate trauma at the University of California. She explained more about the condition to Graihagh Jackson, host of BBC World Service programme, The Climate Question.

transcript.author: Jyoti Mishra
transcript.text: Climate trauma is not an individual trauma , it's a community-wide trauma which really requires community-wide healing.

transcript.author: Graihagh Jackson
transcript.text: Yeah, I'm really struck by what you've said about the fact that it's whole communities that are affected, not individuals, but also part of the solution is about the community and how it rebuilds and reknits together.

transcript.author: Jyoti Mishra
transcript.text: Absolutely, yes. So, we've found that individuals who have a greater sense of positive support from their family and a greater sense of meaningful connection with their community — they are in general more resilient.

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: Jyoti's research on climate trauma has found that it affects communities rather than individuals.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Host of the programme Graihagh Jackson is struck by what Jyoti says. If you're struck by an idea, you find it particularly interesting or impressive.

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: Graihagh says that part of the solution to climate trauma could be in how the community reknits together . This means how the social connections in a community are restored. We can often describe a community as close-knit , which means everyone helps and supports each other.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Jyoti explains that having a strong community also helps reduce or heal climate trauma. She says that research has found that people who have a strong community are more resilient when bad things, like natural disasters, happen. If you're resilient , you're able to get better more easily after something difficult or bad happens.

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: One person who had to be resilient is Brad Sherwood. He survived a wildfire in Northern California in 2017 called the Tubbs fire, but when he returned home, his neighbourhood was destroyed.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Brad started to volunteer for a local support network called After the Fire to try to rebuild his community, as he explained to BBC World Service programme, The Climate Question.

transcript.author: Brad Sherwood
transcript.text: The silver lining in all this — I mean, if it wasn't for the Tubbs fire, we wouldn't be working as a community right now to build a new community plaza. We were a close community before the Tubbs, but afterwards we are so much stronger and resilient . And I think our children are as well. They can jump over any hurdle .

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: Brad says that the work to rebuild and improve his community is the silver lining to the fire. The expression silver lining means a positive thing that comes from a negative situation.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Brad's community became more resilient after the fire, including the children. He says that they can jump over any hurdle. We can describe challenges or difficult things in life as hurdles .

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: And it's quite inspiring, I think, to hear how Brad has taken a bad situation and tried to stay resilient. Now, the organisation Brad volunteers for, After the Fire, are helping those impacted by the fires in LA in January.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Which reminds me, I asked you, Beth, about the impacts of human-made climate change on the wildfires in LA in January.

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: And I said 10% more likely.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Which was, I'm afraid, the wrong answer. It was actually 35%.

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: Wow. OK. Well, let's recap the vocabulary we've learnt, starting with trauma , which is what we call the very bad and long-lasting emotional effects of an event or experience.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: If you're struck by an idea or something someone has said, you find it particularly interesting or impressive.

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: If a community reknits together , it becomes closer again. And a close-knit community is where everyone looks after each other.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Resilient means able to get better more easily when bad things happen.

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: A silver lining is a positive thing that comes from a negative situation.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And we can describe challenges or difficult things in life as hurdles .
